abstract.p: Some kitschy roadside signs have been in the news lately; 40-foot cowboy outside Pioneer Club in Las Vegas, Nev, has been spruced up and repaired; Mr Potato Head statues in Rhode Island have been targets for vandalism and theft; life-size Ronald McDonald figure taken from Portland, Ore, restaurant in early 1980s and held for ransom has been recovered (M)

block.p: For some reason, the kitschy plastic figures so beloved of roadside businesses for generations are all over the news lately.

From Las Vegas comes word that Vegas Vic, the 40-foot cowboy that has beckoned passersby into the Pioneer Club for half a century, is booming his hearty ''Howdy, pardner'' down Fremont Street again after long-postponed repairs to his voice box; he's also sporting fresh paint and neon tubing.

From Las Vegas comes word that Vegas Vic, the 40-foot cowboy that has beckoned passersby into the Pioneer Club for half a century, is booming his hearty ''Howdy, pardner'' down Fremont Street again after long-postponed repairs to his voice box; he's also sporting fresh paint and neon tubing.

In Rhode Island, 6-foot statues of Mr. Potato Head installed around the state to proclaim it ''the birthplace of fun'' (Hasbro got its start in Pawtucket) have, perhaps predictably, come in for considerable vandalism, including one spudnapping -- no mean feat, considering the 136-pound, $3,500 statues are bolted to concrete bases.

Best of all, a life-size Ronald McDonald figure, stolen from a Portland, Ore., restaurant in the early 1980's, turned up last Thursday in the basement of a rented house. Except for three broken fingers, Ronald was intact, including his disco-era pageboy hairstyle. The police said they think they know who swiped Ronald and tried unsuccessfully to ransom him back for a few thousand Big Macs, but the crime is too old to prosecute.
